316.81.text:
Christianity had gained much ground by Constantine's
death in 337, and never looked back. But Christianity

323.51.text:

complex mix of competing beliefs and traditions,

329.08.text:
at the heart of which was the conundrum of
the Trinity: God the Father, God the Son,

334.99.text:
and God the Holy Ghost. To try to resolve
difficulties, Constantine convened a Council

340.83.text:
in 325 at his palace of Nicaea, (Iznik in
modern Turkey) - just across the Bosphorus

347.25.text:
from Constantinople. This Council of bishops
and other ecclesiastical heavyweights eventually

353.81.text:
led to the Nicene Creed, which remains fundamental
to almost all Christian denominations. The

361.01.text:
Council sought to address the problem of the
Trinity, of who came first. I have to beware

366.90.text:
getting us much involved in this complex issue,
but we must touch on it to understand the

371.66.text:
kind of Christianity that permeated the lives
of all who lived in Christendom, of which

376.35.text:
Britannia would be a member as a province
of the Roman Empire in the fourth century.

382.29.text:
The dispute was about the 'Substance' of the
Trinity - perhaps, the Mystery is a better

word. Which was the most senior of the Three
in One Godhead? God the Father and God the

393.70.text:

there was no accord on whether the Son was

398.28.text:
there at the Beginning, with His Father, or
just before Creation, or just after it, and

404.00.text:

408.35.text:
not sorted that out theologically, and the
Christian belief in the Trinity of Three in
